title: Don Pasquale review: Mainly good fun in these dark times
text:
Don Pasquale

Royal Opera House, London Until November 2

Rating:

Is Bryn Terfel growing up too quickly? In his new role this magnificent boyo, still in his absolute prime, plays Donizetti’s Don Pasquale, a doddery old miser. Pasquale is a part for a master patter merchant, and trying to get his tongue around some extremely tricky comic business, Bryn shows he is not quite the equal of buffo baritones like Alessandro Corbelli.

But Corbelli doesn’t sing Wotan, whereas Terfel does. His extraordinary versatility is rightly making him the stuff of legend.

Here Terfel shares the honours with the conductor Evelino Pidò, whose phrasing of the overture (played, thankfully, with the curtain down) is an absolute joy.

Bryn Terfel as Don Pasquale shows he is not quite the equal of buffo baritones like Alessandro Corbelli and the Russian soprano Olga Peretyatko looks good and sings well

The supporting cast is Covent Garden’s usual motley, multi-national crew, without a single Italian. The Russian soprano Olga Peretyatko, making her debut, looks good and sings well but without any real idiomatic feel for this music.

Similarly, the Romanian tenor Ioan Hotea is possessed of a pleasingly accurate high tenor voice but one entirely lacking in romantic allure or the merest taste of Italian honey.

IT'S A FACT Don Pasquale is a prime example of 'opera buffa', or comic opera, based on the stock characters from commedia dell'arte.

As for Markus Werba’s Malatesta, he’s an experienced international baritone but why import an Austrian when there are plenty of outstanding British baritones on the Northern Line?

The Italian director Damiano Michieletto’s William Tell provoked outrage with a gratuitously violent sexual assault on a woman with a broken bottle. His later, Olivier Award-winning Cav and Pag was much better, as it needed to be.

This expensive-looking modern setting of Pasquale is also properly house-trained, containing little or nothing to raise your blood pressure.

It’s mainly good fun, and why not in these dark times? It’s in the cinemas on Thursday. Do go.

Don Pasquale, Royal Opera House Live cinema season, October 24, roh.org.uk

ALBUM OF THE WEEK

Jonas Kaufmann Wien Sony, out now

Rating:

This imaginative album from Jonas Kaufmann contains not just Viennese music but Viennese songs and arias about the city. It’s very well sung, with only a few signs of the vocal problems that have afflicted him in recent years.

It’s also well accompanied by the Vienna Philharmonic under Adám Fischer and, at 78 minutes, is excellent value.

The Johann Strauss items include few of the usual suspects. The only well-known aria is Franz Lehár’s Lippen Schweigen from The Merry Widow, a duet with Rachel Willis-Sørensen.

This imaginative album from Jonas Kaufmann contains not just Viennese music but Viennese songs and arias about the city

It’s good to be taken off the beaten track with two songs by Robert Stolz, the last of the waltz kings, and items by unknowns, at least to me, such as Rudolf Sieczynski and Hans May.

May’s two songs come from a 1935 movie starring the ill-fated tenor Joseph Schmidt, who died aged just 38.

The second of these, Es Wird Im Leben… is very touching and shows that Kaufmann is happy to engage with Austria’s murky past, as well as its joyous one.

He ends with another Jewish composer, Georg Kreisler and his cynical view of Vienna where, as Kaufmann says, ‘Kreisler illuminates his Vienna and his Jewish roots with a healthy dose of sarcasm.’
